descendants.content:
@FantasticalEconomics @WarnerCrocker

Is it still global if the graph seems to show seasonality? Perhaps the cycle varies with distance from the sun too, but that graph seems to reflect the cycle of a single hemisphere, the northern hemisphere (I know, it is the change from the former mean that is important, just questioning the use of ‘global’ for data that seems hemisphere specific)

account.note: Fifteen years at the other place. Post Punk tech Luddite. First toot June 2 2023.

descendants.content:
@Chancerubbage

Great question! I had to look it up. Good news is it's due to geography, not bias for the global north.

"This is because the seasonal patterns of the northern hemisphere drive the overall global temperatures. The large land masses of the northern hemisphere warm up faster than the oceans of the southern hemisphere can cool down during the northern summer months."

https://climate.copernicus.eu/new-record-daily-global-average-temperature-reached-july-2024

@WarnerCrocker

account.note:
I'm an environmental economist who researches econ pedagogy to make learning economics marginally less dismal.

My pipe-dream is to write a fantasy novel/economics textbook, which is getting closer to reality every day.

#economics #TeachEcon #sustainability #DoughnutEconomics #degrowth

Profile pic is me smiling in front of a whiteboard with economics gibberish -- cause econ makes me happy.

Background is my dog, Freya, who is derpily sticking her tongue out while passed out.

fields.name: About me
fields.value: Making econ marginally less dismal one post at a time. I teach economics at the UC Denver and am an all around nerd. My goal is to combine my passion for all things fantasy/sci-fi and love of economics to lower the cost of learning econ.

descendants.content:
@FantasticalEconomics
Where I am living (Tasmania, Australia) everyones complaining about the cold (coldest start to winter in many decades in places) with the occasional anecdote, "so much for global warming." I try and stop my eyes rolling

https://xkcd.com/1321/

account.note:
I am here to learn and face the truth, not avoid it and sometimes this can alas lead to confrontation when others prefer the latter to the former.

Matrix Account: @hanrahan:matrix.org

descendants.content:
@largess

Ha. I haven't seen that comic, but it sums it up nicely.

Not to mention another aspect of climate change is increased variability. More extreme extremes.

I'm sure if I've looked hard enough we'd find the hands of fossil fuel marketing on the phrase "so much for global warming." I doubt they were the first to use the phrase, but there is no chance they haven't helped promote the use of it.

descendants.content:
@FantasticalEconomics @largess

The analogy I came up with a decade ago was the kind of transition in the kind of bubbles in a pan. Compare and contrast a pan at simmer vs rolling boil. The temp isn’t that different, but the state is, at least if you’re some little mote hoping for a quiet life with mild disruptions here and there.
